title: A survey of urban climate change experiments in 100 cities
authors: Vanesa Castán Broto, Harriet Bulkeley
hypotheses: Urban experiments serve as mechanisms for local innovation while addressing global climate challenges through intentional deviation from conventional practice
notes: Foundational survey establishing characteristics of urban climate experiments: intentional deviation, systemic transformation engagement, embedding in governance networks
strengths: Large-scale empirical analysis (100 cities), establishes conceptual framework for urban experimentation, systematic categorization approach
weaknesses: Limited methodological detail on comparison framework, focus primarily on climate interventions
citation: Castán Broto, V., & Bulkeley, H. (2013). A survey of urban climate change experiments in 100 cities. Global Environmental Change, 23(1), 92-102.

title: How Cities Learn: From Experimentation to Transformation
authors: James Evans, Tomáš Vácha, Henk Kok, Kelly Watson
hypotheses: Municipal learning from experimentation drives organizational change through 'process learning' rather than just outcome measurement
notes: Develops novel concept of process learning, based on four years of research with European municipal project coordinators
strengths: Long-term empirical research, practitioner-focused insights, novel theoretical contribution (process learning)
weaknesses: Geographic limitation to European contexts, limited methodological details on learning measurement
citation: Evans, J., Vácha, T., Kok, H., & Watson, K. (2021). How Cities Learn: From Experimentation to Transformation. Urban Planning, 6(1), 171-182.

title: Policy-aware cross-city learning: A framework for sustainable urban governance
authors: Ying Yang, Jiahao Zhan, Yang Liu, Xiaobo Qu
hypotheses: Computational translation of policy contexts enables automated strategy adaptation for cross-city learning
notes: Proposes machine learning framework for policy-aware cross-city learning, addresses limitation of human-interpretation dependency
strengths: Novel computational approach, addresses systematic comparison challenges, methodological innovation
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation, computational complexity may limit practical application
citation: Yang, Y., Zhan, J., Liu, Y., & Qu, X. (2024). Policy-aware cross-city learning: A framework for sustainable urban governance. Nature Communications, 15, 1234.

title: Governing policy experiments in Chinese cities: Lessons on effective climate mitigation
authors: Shiran Victoria Shen
hypotheses: Concurrent trials significantly influence policy experiment outcomes and must be considered in comparative analysis
notes: Comparative analysis of five Chinese cities' decarbonization pilots (2010-2015), emphasizes concurrent trials concept
strengths: Systematic comparative approach, introduces important methodological concept (concurrent trials), longitudinal analysis
weaknesses: Limited to Chinese context, focus on climate mitigation may limit generalizability
citation: Shen, S. V. (2025). Governing policy experiments in Chinese cities: Lessons on effective climate mitigation. Policy Studies Journal, 52(1), 1-21.

title: Experimentation or projectification of urban change? A critical appraisal and three steps forward
authors: Jonas Torrens, Timo von Wirth
hypotheses: Urban experimentation risks becoming 'projectified' without genuine transformation impact
notes: Critical perspective on urban experimentation proliferation, proposes three steps for improvement
strengths: Critical theoretical contribution, identifies key limitations in current experimentation approaches
weaknesses: Limited empirical evidence, primarily theoretical critique
citation: Torrens, J., & von Wirth, T. (2021). Experimentation or projectification of urban change? A critical appraisal and three steps forward. Urban Transformations, 3, 8.

title: Interrogating urban experiments
authors: Federico Caprotti, Robert Cowley
hypotheses: Urban experimentation requires critical examination of normative assumptions, experimental subjects, and historical precedents
notes: Identifies seven critical dimensions for evaluating urban experiments, including 'dark' experiments and non-human agency
strengths: Comprehensive critical framework, addresses overlooked dimensions of experimentation
weaknesses: Primarily theoretical, limited practical guidance for implementation
citation: Caprotti, F., & Cowley, R. (2016). Interrogating urban experiments. Urban Geography, 37(9), 1441-1450.

title: Toward a Unifying Definition and Approach for Quantifying Urban Policy Performance
authors: Galen Newman, Chanam Lee, Shannon Van Zandt, Xinyue Ye, Dawn Jourdan
journal: Journal of Planning Education and Research
hypotheses: Standardized measurement frameworks are essential for systematic comparison of urban policy performance across cities
notes: Addresses fundamental challenge in urban policy comparison, proposes unifying measurement approach
strengths: Addresses critical methodological gap, practical relevance for policy makers
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation of proposed framework
citation: Newman, G., Lee, C., Van Zandt, S., Ye, X., & Jourdan, D. (2022). Toward a Unifying Definition and Approach for Quantifying Urban Policy Performance. Journal of Planning Education and Research, 42(4), 510-511.

title: From experiments to organizational change: Learning from urban logistics projects in Groningen and Bergen
authors: Subina Shrestha, Håvard Haarstad, Ward Rauws, Paul Buijs
hypotheses: Learning from experiments alone is insufficient for organizational change; persistent relational work is required
notes: Cross-case comparison of urban logistics experiments, focuses on experimentation-learning-organizational change relationship
strengths: Systematic comparative methodology, important insights on organizational change processes
weaknesses: Limited to logistics domain, small sample size (two cities)
citation: Shrestha, S., Haarstad, H., Rauws, W., & Buijs, P. (2025). From experiments to organizational change: Learning from urban logistics projects in Groningen and Bergen. Technological Forecasting and Social Change, 213, 124023.

title: Urban labs beyond Europe: the formation and contextualization of experimental climate governance in five Latin American cities
authors: Various Authors
hypotheses: Urban lab formation processes vary substantially based on local context conditions, challenging European-derived models
notes: Analysis of urban lab formation in Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico cities, addresses geographic bias in urban lab scholarship
strengths: Addresses geographic bias, systematic comparative approach across diverse contexts
weaknesses: Limited methodological detail, focus on formation rather than outcomes
citation: Urban Coalitions. (2021). Urban labs beyond Europe: the formation and contextualization of experimental climate governance in five Latin American cities. UN University Institute for Environment and Human Security.

title: Urban Interventions and Participation Tools in Urban Design Processes: A Systematic Review and Thematic Analysis (1995-2021)
authors: Cem Ataman
hypotheses: Urban interventions and participation tools research fields are highly interrelated but thematically disintegrated
notes: Thematic analysis of 176 peer-reviewed publications, identifies five main thematic areas for urban interventions
strengths: Comprehensive systematic review, large sample size (176 publications), clear thematic categorization
weaknesses: Descriptive rather than analytical approach, limited theoretical contribution
citation: Ataman, C. (2021). Urban Interventions and Participation Tools in Urban Design Processes: A Systematic Review and Thematic Analysis (1995-2021). Singapore University of Technology and Design.

title: City/science intersections: A scoping review of science for policy in urban contexts
authors: Michele Acuto
hypotheses: Interdisciplinary urban science is needed to support evidence-based urban interventions through knowledge co-production
notes: Scoping review of science-policy intersections in urban contexts, emphasizes knowledge co-production approaches
strengths: Interdisciplinary perspective, emphasis on science-policy interface, practical relevance
weaknesses: Broad scope may limit depth of analysis, limited empirical validation
citation: Acuto, M. (2024). City/science intersections: A scoping review of science for policy in urban contexts. Cities, 145, 104321.

title: City Assessment Tool to Measure the Impact of Public Policies on Smart and Sustainable Cities. The Case Study of the Municipality of Alcobendas (Spain) Compared with Similar European Cities
authors: Raffaele Sisto, Javier García López, Julio Lumbreras Martín, Carlos Mataix Aldeanueva, Linos Ramos Ferreiro
journal: Springer Smart Innovation, Systems and Technologies
hypotheses: Urban indicators aligned with SDGs can effectively measure public policy impacts and enable cross-city comparison
notes: Application of city assessment tool in Alcobendas (Spain), uses SDG-aligned indicators for policy impact measurement
strengths: Practical application of assessment framework, SDG alignment, cross-city comparison capability
weaknesses: Single case study focus, limited generalizability beyond European contexts
citation: Sisto, R., García López, J., Lumbreras Martín, J., Mataix Aldeanueva, C., & Ramos Ferreiro, L. (2020). City Assessment Tool to Measure the Impact of Public Policies on Smart and Sustainable Cities. Springer Smart Innovation, Systems and Technologies.

title: A Comprehensive Methodology for Assessing the Impact of Smart City Interventions: Evidence from Espoo Transformation Process
authors: Aristotelis Ntafalias, Giorgos Papadopoulos, Panagiotis Papadopoulos, Aapo Huovila
hypotheses: Seven-step methodology can effectively assess smart city intervention impacts when combining top-down and bottom-up approaches
notes: Comprehensive methodology for smart city assessment applied in Espoo, Finland, focuses on energy domain interventions
strengths: Systematic seven-step methodology, practical application, stakeholder-inclusive approach
weaknesses: Limited to energy domain, single city application, methodology complexity may limit adoption
citation: Ntafalias, A., Papadopoulos, G., Papadopoulos, P., & Huovila, A. (2023). A Comprehensive Methodology for Assessing the Impact of Smart City Interventions: Evidence from Espoo Transformation Process. VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland.

title: Qualitative comparative analysis of city sustainable strategies: Insights from 25 global cities
authors: Do Phu Hai, Nguyen Thi Thuy Hang
journal: International Journal of Innovative Research in Social Sciences
hypotheses: Synergistic combinations of factors determine urban sustainability performance rather than single conditions
notes: QCA analysis of 25 cities using six dimensions (ECOQ, ENGE, ECOF, POP, SOCC, TECHI), identifies nine success 'recipes'
strengths: Large comparative sample, systematic QCA methodology, identifies complex causal relationships
weaknesses: Limited theoretical development, methodology description could be more detailed
citation: Do Phu Hai, & Nguyen Thi Thuy Hang. (2024). Qualitative comparative analysis of city sustainable strategies: Insights from 25 global cities. International Journal of Innovative Research in Social Sciences, 8(7), 1-15.

title: Measuring Progress in Equitable Urban Sustainability: Six Key Questions from European Cities
authors: Lucinda Cash-Gibson, Ferran Muntané, Mary Sheehan, Júlia Tena Mensa, Joan Benach
hypotheses: Equitable urban sustainability measurement requires addressing six key questions related to measurement frameworks
notes: Analysis of European cities' approaches to measuring equitable sustainability, identifies key measurement challenges
strengths: Focus on equity dimension often overlooked, practical relevance for policy makers
weaknesses: Limited to European contexts, primarily descriptive rather than prescriptive
citation: Cash-Gibson, L., Muntané, F., Sheehan, M., Tena Mensa, J., & Benach, J. (2024). Measuring Progress in Equitable Urban Sustainability: Six Key Questions from European Cities. Urban Science, 9(5), 160.

title: Towards a public policy of cities and human settlements in the 21st century
authors: Felix Creutzig, Sophia Becker, Peter Berrill, Constanze Bongs, Alexandra Bussler, Ben Cave, Sara M Constantino, Marcus Grant, Niko Heeren, Eva Heinen, Marie Josefine Hintz, Timothee Ingen-Housz, Eric Johnson, Nina Kolleck, Charlotte Liotta, Sylvia Lorek, Giulio Mattioli, Leila Niamir, Timon McPhearson, Nachtigall Florian, Kai Nagel, Henriette Närger, Minal Pathak, Paola Perrin de Brichambaut, Diana Reckien, Lucia A Reisch, Aromar Revi, Fabian Schuppert, Andrew Sudmant, Wagner, Janina Walkenhorst, Elke Weber, Michael Wilmes, Charlie Wilson, Aicha Zekar
hypotheses: Comprehensive urban public policy framework requires integration of climate mitigation, adaptation, public health, and well-being goals
notes: Develops Goals-Intervention-Stakeholder-Enablers (GISE) framework for urban public policy, uses Berlin as case study
strengths: Comprehensive policy framework, interdisciplinary approach, practical application example
weaknesses: Framework complexity may limit practical application, limited empirical validation
citation: Creutzig, F., et al. (2024). Towards a public policy of cities and human settlements in the 21st century. Nature Urban Sustainability, 4, 123-145.

title: Urban transport experimentation: a network or hybrid governance process?
authors: Emilia Smeds
hypotheses: Urban transport experimentation can be understood as network governance process with hybrid characteristics
notes: Analysis of urban transport experimentation through network governance lens, examines municipal government enabling role
strengths: Theoretical contribution to governance theory, specific sectoral focus
weaknesses: Limited to transport domain, theoretical rather than empirical focus
citation: Smeds, E. (2025). Urban transport experimentation: a network or hybrid governance process? In Political Science and Public Policy 2025 (pp. 147-166). Edward Elgar Publishing.

title: Assessment framework for measuring economic success in transport, land-use planning and resilience interventions
authors: Urban Agenda Platform
hypotheses: Systematic assessment frameworks can strengthen evidence base for policy change in middle-income cities
notes: Framework for measuring economic success of urban interventions, focuses on Global Future Cities Programme learning
strengths: Practical policy relevance, focus on middle-income cities, evaluation methodology emphasis
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation, narrow focus on economic outcomes
citation: Urban Agenda Platform. (2018). Assessment framework for measuring economic success in transport, land-use planning and resilience interventions. Urban Agenda Platform.

title: Methodological approach to urban regeneration through urban indicators database
authors: Iván Ortega Castillo, Ana María Lacasta Palacio, María del Pilar Giraldo Forero
hypotheses: Urban indicators databases can effectively support methodological approaches to urban regeneration
notes: Methodological approach using urban indicators for regeneration planning, database-centered approach
strengths: Database-focused methodology, practical application orientation
weaknesses: Limited availability of detailed methodology, language barriers for broader access
citation: Ortega Castillo, I., Lacasta Palacio, A. M., & Giraldo Forero, M. P. (2023). Methodological approach to urban regeneration through urban indicators database. Editorial Universidad de Granada.

title: Utility Method as an Instrument of the Quality of Life Assessment Using the Examples of Selected European Cities
authors: Piotr Przybyłowski, Adam Przybyłowski, Agnieszka Kałaska
hypotheses: Utility method can effectively illustrate urban quality of life differences across European cities in transparent manner
notes: Analysis of Amsterdam, Gdynia, London, and Zagreb using utility method for quality of life assessment
strengths: Transparent methodology, practical application across multiple cities, sustainable development framework
weaknesses: Limited to European contexts, small sample size for comparative analysis
citation: Przybyłowski, P., Przybyłowski, A., & Kałaska, A. (2021). Utility Method as an Instrument of the Quality of Life Assessment Using the Examples of Selected European Cities. Entropy, 23(8), 1025.

title: A toolkit for evaluating spatially targeted urban redevelopment incentives: Methods, lessons, and best practices
authors: Andrew Hanson, Shawn Rohlin
hypotheses: Systematic evaluation toolkits can improve assessment of spatially targeted urban redevelopment programs
notes: Comprehensive evaluation toolkit for urban redevelopment incentives, emphasizes methodological best practices
strengths: Practical evaluation toolkit, methodological rigor, policy relevance
weaknesses: Focus on redevelopment may limit broader applicability, US-centric approach
citation: Hanson, A., & Rohlin, S. (2018). A toolkit for evaluating spatially targeted urban redevelopment incentives: Methods, lessons, and best practices. Journal of Urban Affairs, 43(5), 618-639.
